did.unittitle: Isabelle Hallin Papers

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into one series.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Isabelle Louise Hallin was born in Saugus, Massachusetts on March 29, 1912 to Annie L. Hallin and Carl Fred Hallin. She graduated from Saugus High School in 1929 and went on to study at Jackson College, where she graduated in 1933.

Isabelle Hallin began teaching freshman and sophomore English at Saugus High School in November 1934. She organized a dramatic club at the school, directing and producing six three-act plays and several one-act plays in the three years she worked at the school.

In May 1937, Hallin invited students to her parents' house after school to practice for a performance of "Seventeen," because the school facility was too cold at the time. Shortly after this, rumors began to circulate in town that she had thrown a cocktail party for her underage students.

As the rumors spread, Minnie B. McDuffee of the Women's Christian Temperance Union decided to take action against the young teacher. She expressed her outrage at Hallin's alleged actions, and soon Saugus School Board member Maria Smith called for Hallin's resignation. Smith, along with two other members of the school board, Harry Wentworth and Waldo B. Russell, voted to not renew Hallin's contract with the school. Hallin hired an attorney named Daniel Canning to fight her dismissal. She also brought a case against Minnie B. McDuffee for slander.

News of Isabelle Hallin's situation and her campaign to get her job back made national headlines. Time Magazine ran an article titled "Storm in Saugus" on July 19, 1937. Articles about her also appeared in the Oakland Tribune, the New York Evening Post, the Boston Globe, True Story magazine, and a number of other papers throughout the country. Hallin also made several radio appearances to tell her side of the story.

In July 1937, the Saugus School Board voted 3-2 to deny Isabelle Hallin a public hearing to discuss her dismissal. George E. McCarrier and Paul A. Haley supported her reinstatement and were the dissenting votes in the losing battle for a public hearing. During the meeting, school board member Waldo B. Russell claimed that Hallin's dismissal was not motivated by the cocktail party rumors, but by poor performance and over-commitment to extracurricular activities, such as the dramatic productions. Maria Smith and Waldo B. Russell, two of the school board members who voted against a public hearing, required police escort to their homes after the meeting to avoid confronting approximately 500 angry protesters who had gathered outside.

In August 1937, Hallin moved to New York City to take the position of Junior Copywriter at Montgomery Ward, a department retailer. Following an illness, she came back to the greater Boston area in 1938, where she worked for the radio station WAAB of the Mutual Broadcasting System and the Salem Express. She relocated to New York again in October 1938, taking up seasonal employment at the jewelry retailer, Finlay Straus. In January 1939 she began working in advertising for the Eastern Isles Importing Company.

During this time period, Hallin began showing signs of depression and withdrew from family and friends. She rarely returned to Saugus due to the stress caused her by the rumors that had marred her name. Hallin was particularly upset by the effect these rumors had on her parents. A reporter named William Brawders, who visited Hallin in New York, wrote in a December 28, 1941 Salem Sunday Express article entitled "The Poor Girl Never Had a Chance," that during his visit he "learned that she condemned herself to exile for lifetime, to the hope she was giving happiness to her mother and dad."

On December 24, 1941 Isabelle Hallin turned on the gas stove, went to sleep, and died in her New York apartment in an apparent suicide. The cause of death was listed as "asphyxia by illuminating gas." Eleven days later, the Saugus School Committee unanimously voted to posthumously absolve Hallin of all charges against her name and character.

In March 2013, after a public campaign organized by Peter Manoogian, the town of Saugus dedicated a plaque to Isabelle Hallin in the Town Hall. The plaque reads, "May our actions within this Town Hall lead to greater wisdom and justice rather than sorrow and regret."

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This collection was assembled by Peter Manoogian, who brought together Isabelle Hallin's papers inherited by her nephew Laurence Hallin and Mr. Manoogian's own additions purchased in online auctions.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed in August 2014 by Dan Bullman under the supervision of Liz Francis (Records Archivist). Dan and Liz decided to maintain the original order of collection donor Peter Manoogian's arrangement, with the exception of oversize items, which are arranged at the end of the collection. Items in binders were removed to folders and maintained in the original order of the binder pages. Folder titles created by archival staff are listed in brackets []. Isabelle Hallin's folder, which contained a single photograph, from UA073 Vertical file collection was also removed to MS219. Separation sheets were filed in both collections and a note has been made in the CIDER record for UA073.008.VF.00087 Hallin, Isabelle J1933.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains photographs, news clippings, correspondence, college class assignment papers, poetry, and a scrapbook from Isabelle Hallin's personal collection, inherited by her nephew Laurence Hallin. The collection also contains news clippings, photocopies of documents, photographs, and news items, interview transcripts, correspondence, and magazines compiled by Peter Manoogian during his research on Isabelle Hallin. Miss Hallin was fired from her teaching job at Saugus High School in 1937 after rumors circulated that she had provided alcohol to several students who had gone to her parents' home for theater practice one evening. The bulk of the material in the collection relates to Isabelle Hallin's efforts to retain her job and later to appeal her termination. This includes correspondence with relatives, friends, administrators, and supporters of her efforts to retain her position.

Also of interest are news clippings and photographs from theater productions that Hallin participated in or attended during high school, college, and afterwards. This includes programs from the Garrick Players, Pen Paint and Pretzels, and the Saugus High School Dramatic Society.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

did.unittitle: Isabelle Hallin papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs, news clippings, correspondence, college class assignment papers, poetry, and a scrapbook from Isabelle Hallin's personal collection, inherited by her nephew Laurence Hallin. The series also contains news clippings, photocopies of documents, photographs, and news items, interview transcripts, correspondence, and magazines compiled by Peter Manoogian during his research on Isabelle Hallin. Miss Hallin was fired from her teaching job at Saugus High School in 1937 after rumors circulated that she had provided alcohol to several students who had went to her parents' home for theater practice one evening. The bulk of the material in the series relates to Isabelle Hallin's efforts to retain her job and later to appeal her termination. This includes correspondence with relatives, friends, administrators, and supporters of her efforts to retain her position.

Also of interest are news clippings and photographs from theater productions that Hallin participated in or attended during high school, college, and afterwards. This includes programs from the Garrick Players, Pen Paint and Pretzels, and the Saugus High School Dramatic Society.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is organized according to the original order assembled by collection donor, Peter Manoogian, with the exception of oversize items, which are arranged at the end of the series. The series is organized by subject and chronologically within each subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: (Pictures binder 30 of 49). Caption on back of photograph reads: "A personal triumph was scored by Isabelle Hallin, Saugus high school teacher, as she presented her side of school committee ousting to a crowd of 1200 in Saugus town hall last night. She is seen being cheered by youthful supporters as she left the demonstration."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This scrapbook was compiled by Isabelle Hallin and primarily contains items from her time as a student at Jackson College (1930-33). The book contains photographs of Hallin, news clippings about classmates, a variety of fraternity booklets, and theater programs from Pen Paint and Pretzels.

did.unittitle: Isabelle Hallin high school diploma from Saugus High School
Tufts and Jackson Class of 1933 graduation photograph

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a panorama photograph of the Tufts College and Jackson College graduating classes of 1933. Isabelle Hallin is identified in the photograph.
